description: An ancient city on the Euphrates River's West bank, established perhaps as early as the Hittite period. Its ruins, known in modern times as Samsat (Turkey), were submerged following the construction of the Atatürk Dam in the early 1990s. The modern village of Samsat was relocated and is not coincident with the ancient site.

names.description: Reconstructed Latin name (transliteration?), attested on an early third-century honorific inscription from Rome. "Samosate" (found on the stone) is presumed to be an odd or failed attempt at the locative case.

names.description: Name of a country in eastern Anatolia whose capital city has the same name and is identified with classical Samosata and modern Samsat. A place name from the TAVO Index (Vol. 2, p. 964)
